document.discussion_title: DPS expands training to include autism, communication problems
document.topic_text: 10:10 DPS expands training to include autism, communication problems Major Jason Hester, of the DPS Education, Training and Research Division, said the department did not see a need for the program before being approached by Aspergers101, an advocacy group for people with the communication impediment, but officials felt... Share on Facebook Tweet AUSTIN - The Texas Department of Public Safety will expand its officer training to include interacting with people with autism, one of several initiatives the agency announced Monday to help with traffic stops involving motorists with communication difficulties.The state will also expand the definition of "communication impediment," which appears on drivers licenses if a person chooses. The label previously was aimed at protecting deaf people, but now will be available for those with autism or Aspergers.Major Jason Hester, of the DPS Education, Training and Research Division, said the department did not see a need for the program before being approached by Aspergers101, an advocacy group for people with the communication impediment, but officials felt a responsibility to implement the program."We don't have any documented incidents," Hester said. "However, we just think that it was a great initiative to have the additional information, to have that out there. We have a responsibility to provide for a safer Texas."Aspergers101 is also collaborating with the agency in providing summer camps that help people with communication impediments learn how to drive and interact with police officers.
